bboxes.raw_text:
The Future Teachers of
America of Palmdale School,
3l46 E. Wier, has char
name to the G. Benjamin Brooks
chapter.


New officers insta lied recently
are Patricia Perryman, pre- 81
dent; Minnie Johnson, vice presi-
dent; Viola Wooten, secretary
Thelma Reynolds, trea surer;
Curtis Hayes, historian; and
Joyce Davis, parliamentarian.


Faculty advisors are Miss
Ethel Daniels and Mrs. Juanita
Patterson.


Rev. l.. K. Williams, pastor of
Tanner Chapel AME Church was
the guest speaker.


Rev. C. B. Brooks wa also
guest.


installations we're made by Al
bridge Keith, a teacher at the
school and a member of the
Roosevelt eta.

Rod ]. McMullin, general man
ager of the Salt River Project,
has been elected president OF
the Heard Museum for the 1864
IS sea son.


McMullin succeeds Edward ia
cobson, who now becomes board
member. Other trustees are
Sherman Hazeltine, first vice
president; Larry Laughlin, sec
ond vice-president: Mrs. Richard
Burgess, secretary; and Frank
w. Clelland, Jr.. trea surer.


McMullin began his first term
on the Heard board of trustees
three years ago. He is a former
vice-president and chairman OF
the important Long Range Plan
ming Committee, charged with
charting a course for the future
growth and development of the
museum.

An SOS. (Save Old Sheets)
was issued by the American Can
GER Societys Maricopa County
Unit.


The groups program of pro-
viding free dressings to cancer
patients may be halted because
of the lack of sheets. Dressings
of various sizes needed by the
patients are made by volunteers,
using old, clean sheets.


BY saving your worn or torn
sheets and giving them to the
American Cancer Society you can
reduce the cost and give comfort
to someone suffering from
cancer.


Take sheets to the local Ameri-
can Cancer Society office at 400
North 18th St.

LUKE AFB Colonel Max
S. Kable, Luke Ba Sc Commander,
has been appointed chairman OF
the November %, 1864 Luke
Day s Open House committee by
Colonel Augustus M. Hendry, Jr.,
4SlOth Combat Crew Training
Wing Commander.


The one-day open house will
have over Is different aircraft
on static display World War
and II aircraft, helicopters,
transports. bombers. fighters,
missiles. The program begins
at 800 am. and will end at
$3.50 pm. following a perfor-
nance by the world famous Us.
Air Force Thunderbirds. 1t is
expected to be the largest mill
tary open house in the entire
southwest this year.


Luke officials have conducted
several committee meetings In
preparation for the big day. over
100000 people are expected to
visit the base for this event.


The November date wa S chosen
because of the intense summer
heat during the months OF May
and September, which had pre-
viously been the months for open
houses.


The Air Force Bagpipe Band
from Wa shington, DC. Is ex-
pected to perform. The Golden
Knights official US. Army
Parachute emonstration Team
from Fort Bragg, NC. will give
a sky-diving demonstration.
= Bob Hoover of North Ameri-
can Aviation will perform in a
World War II Psi Mustang.

The fighter without recognition
in his own country is Eddie Per-
kins of Chicago. The world
Junior welter-weight champion
is heralded in foreign places but
seemingly ignored at home.


Eddie relates his predicament
in the November issue of Ebony.
Rhe 27 year old has a host of
fans in Japan, France and South
America, however, few in the
United States know him.

has immediate openings for

on century series aircraft
Requirements are:

certification
